word.entryDescription: a piece of equipment or the part of a fridge in which food can be stored at very cold temperatures
word.entryExample: In the freezer there's some meat and some fish.

word.entryDescription: very cold; below zero degrees Celsius
word.entryExample: Few animals manage to live in freezing climates, but some, amazingly, do.

word.entryDescription: recently produced, or not frozen or preserved
word.entryExample: The ingredients were fresh and it was perfectly cooked.

word.entryDescription: a piece of equipment we use for keeping food at cool temperatures
word.entryExample: The eggs are in the fridge.

word.entryDescription: cooked in oil or fat
word.entryExample: Burgers, chips and fried chicken are examples of fast food.

word.entryDescription: a person you know and like
word.entryExample: Lucy is my best friend.

word.entryDescription: very nervous
word.entryExample: He was frightened that I would complain to his boss.

word.entryDescription: very nervous because of somebody or something
word.entryExample: She is not frightened of asking difficult questions.

word.entryDescription: causing fear
word.entryExample: Horror films are frightening.

word.entryDescription: a small animal with smooth skin that lives in or near water and has long back legs for jumping
word.entryExample: Put the frog in the pond next to the ducks.

word.entryDescription: starting at a particular time or place
word.entryExample: Where are you from?

word.entryDescription: starting at a particular minute
word.entryExample: From the minute I'd got out of bed that day, I'd had a strange feeling in the pit of my stomach.

word.entryDescription: in a position furthest forward
word.entryExample: I was at the front. That's where I sit every day.

word.entryDescription: an area in front of a building where people can do activities outside
word.entryExample: There's a big basketball court on the school frontyard so we can always go there.

word.entryDescription: turned into ice or preserved by freezing
word.entryExample: Where do you put ice cream to keep it frozen?

word.entryDescription: something usually sweet which grows on a plant and contains seeds
word.entryExample: Eat fresh fruit everyday.

word.entryDescription: a dish of different types of fruit cut into pieces and mixed together
word.entryExample: Let's put some more kiwis in our fruit salad.

word.entryDescription: to cook in oil or fat
word.entryExample: Are you going to fry the bacon?

word.entryDescription: a flat open pan used for frying food
word.entryExample: Then, heat a small frying pan with a little oil.

word.entryDescription: the whole name including the first, middle and family name
word.entryExample: Could you give me your full name and address, sir?

word.entryDescription: for the whole time it is usual to work, study, etc
word.entryExample: She used to have a full-time job.

word.entryDescription: pleasure, enjoyment, or entertainment
word.entryExample: We all had good fun at the party.
Sometimes functional devices are necessary to hold clothes together.

word.entryDescription: a kind of tube which is very wide at one end and very narrow at the other, which is used to make it easier to pour liquids into containers with narrow openings
word.entryExample: Tornadoes only occur when the spinning funnel separates from a big cloud mass.

word.entryDescription: something that is funny makes you laugh
word.entryExample: It's a very funny monkey!

word.entryDescription: the thick hair that covers the bodies of many mammals
word.entryExample: Your cat's fur is so soft!

word.entryDescription: the larger objects in a room which make using it comfortable and convenient
word.entryExample: The vandals broke some windows and damaged some furniture in the café.

word.entryDescription: a small device which is clever, useful, interesting, etc
word.entryExample: New ovens and cooking gadgets arrived in Britain from the United States in the 1950s.

word.entryDescription: to get or to get more of
word.entryExample: Biographies are a fantastic way to gain knowledge of why people acted in the way that they did.

word.entryDescription: a very strong wind
word.entryExample: Britain gets storms too, with gales, thunder and lightning, so sometimes it's best to stay indoors.

word.entryDescription: a public building where you can look at works of art
word.entryExample: What do you do in a gallery?

word.entryDescription: an entertaining activity played to certain rules
word.entryExample: Would you like to play a game of chess with me?

word.entryDescription: a year between finishing school and starting university or college when you travel or work
word.entryExample: I'm going to take a gap year after school and get some work experience.

word.entryDescription: a room or building in which you keep your car
word.entryExample: Is the car on the drive or in the garage?

word.entryDescription: an area of grass and flowers outside a house
word.entryExample: We're playing in the garden.

word.entryDescription: item of clothing
word.entryExample: Hats are garments with a lot of different uses.

word.entryDescription: a substance in the same form as air, but it can be burned and used for cooking and heating
word.entryExample: I'm particularly concerned about pollution, so I agree with Andy that we need to stop burning fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas.

word.entryDescription: a place to buy petrol in the USA
word.entryExample: Excuse me, how far is it to the nearest gas station?

word.entryDescription: a door in an outside wall or fence
word.entryExample: Please, can you shut the gate so the dog can't get out!

word.entryDescription: to give a long look often in a dreamy way because of admiration, surprise, boredom, etc
word.entryExample: They sat there gazing into each other's eyes.

word.entryDescription: willing to give money, gifts, help, etc to others
word.entryExample: He is a generous man. He loves to give expensive presents.

word.entryDescription: doing things carefully or softly so as not to harm something
word.entryExample: Please be more gentle with the cat.

word.entryDescription: the study of the earth's physical features, and human activity and organisation according to area
word.entryExample: They went outside to take pictures of the weather for geography.

word.entryDescription: relating to the heat at the centre of the Earth
word.entryExample: Geothermal energy is one of the renewable energy sources.

word.entryDescription: receive something
word.entryExample: I always get a nice present for my birthday from my parents.
I've never been so happy in my life to get back early from a holiday!

word.entryDescription: to put your clothes on your body
word.entryExample: I get dressed then I have breakfast.

word.entryDescription: to contact somebody
word.entryExample: Could you ask her to get in touch?

word.entryDescription: to enter a place
word.entryExample: The only way to get into the house is by climbing a ladder.

word.entryDescription: to become married
word.entryExample: By next year I will have left my job to get married.
